review_title: Hopefully qualcomm would remain innovation leader for some more time.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Good experience in embedded systems (if you are working in software that is). you will get to work on totally next generation products and concepts.

Great learning experience. Its like working for a big startup
cons:
Pay is slightly below average. The HR department treats you like an object sometimes.
There is no Project Management. Company is turning slowly into a walled company. There is an R&D wall, which throws stuff into the development section sitting accross the wall. The development section either throws the stuff back over from the wall to the R&D or takes it and develops it, then the marketing steps in and a lot more back and forth throwing stuff goes on.  In the end, the lower level and to some extent the middle management lose visibility into whats happening.

job_title: Administrative Supervisor in San Diego, CA
pros:
Great amenities for work-life balance, including company leisure events and cafes.
Friendly and casual atmosphere.
cons: Pushes business and innovation to please shareholders, investors, and to stay ahead of competitors yet continues to reduce work force; adding more work with less people year after year.  Used to be people-oriented, people-valued extraordinary company.  Now it is an ordinary company that is entirely business driven.  That equates to higher employment turn over rates.

review_title: Showing signs of a "big bureaucratic" company, but still a great place to work
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The people working at Qualcomm are by and at large extremely hard working and smart, it is really a pleasure working with folks ther. Also, it is a great place learn new things and grow in your career. Furthermore, the work does not become repetivite and boring, there are always new challenges and experiences
cons: The project schedules at Qualcomm tend to be unrealistic, there is an unwillingness in all levels of management to acknowledge this an plan for it accordingly. As a result, things get really hectic towards the end of a project with sometimes unnecessary sacrifices in quality. Also lately, Qualcomm has suffered from the "too many chiefs, not enough indians" syndrome, everybody is the lead of something, so that there is sometimes nobody to do the actual work and way too much time is spent just reporting status & issues to various higher ups

job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: The pay is excellent and you really are working with the cream of the crop, best of the best, etc. The engineers and designers there are amazing.
cons: The company is cutting the employees' benefits and perks a little every year. When I started a decade ago, everyone got an office, our pay was in the top %ile, insurance was top notch, there were device and education subsidies. Over time, each of these is vanishing; our salaries are median at best, our insurance is okay but not great, our device subsidies have vanished. And the list goes on. It's still an ok company to work for, but it is coasting on a previous reputation, and isn't nearly as great as it once was.

job_title: Director
pros: Excellent technology within Qualcomm, good processes, lots of intelligent people.  Compensation is good, and there are lots of opportunities to learn and improve your skills.
cons: There's a treadmill at Qualcomm - cell-phones and other such products need to hit the market on schedule every year - this doesn't leave a lot of room for fixing things that are broken, or that much innovation.  As well, the best person to do the job this time is probably the same person that did it last time - its easy to get 'stuck'.

job_title: Senior IT Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Good company culture, main campus in San Diego is really nice, free soda and other small perks.
cons:
Too political and difficult to get anything done. Most of the work in IT is CYA and new ideas and projects that don't come from "architects" are rarely listened and backed by management or just blatantly stolen with no credit given.

IT is extremely siloed and pennywise-but-a-pound foolish with budget, spending extraordinary amounts of money on vendor IT software solutions and licenses that 90% of the industry uses for free but balking at small cost incurrences.

Anxiety over job security is high with the recent restructuring due to activist investor influence and shrinking of mobile market revenue.

Promotions in IT are done on a "she was next in line" political process instead of review feedback.

job_title: Staff Engineer in Bridgewater, NJ
pros:
Lots of smart people and interesting work happening in NJ.

Good opportunity if you can align yourself with the right people and projects.

Hard work is usually rewarded.
cons: There is a lot of change happening to Qualcomm right now, and it feels that remote sites (not in CA) are disadvantaged when it comes to the C-level backing on projects.

review_title: Qualcomm is rife with politics and backstabbing.
job_title: Senior Marketing Communications Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: There are alot of smart, hardworking people at Qualcomm, and comraderie and support among coworkers. The pay and the benefits are great.
cons: The company is very heavy with mid-level managers, many who have been there for years and promoted well beyond their skill level. To compensate, the company hires more skilled employees in below them, making the mid-level managers, who these people ultimately report to, feel threatened. Since they are not about to leave--they could never retain their title level and pay elsewhere--there is no place for the newer, more skilled employees to move up. Managers have absolute control, can get away with horrendous verbal abuse, as can any employee who comes under "special protection" of a manager. Human Reousrces is horrible--they will back up an out of control manager and destroy anyone who complains in order to protect the company from lawsuits. There is constant reorganization to hide problem managers, but the individual problems never get addressed, and continue to recur. Anyone who speaks up about it is punished.

review_title: Company in decline, still much potential to turn around
job_title: Principal Engineer/Manager in San Diego, CA
pros:
* Plenty of great talent and sharp engineers
* Latest and greatest technologies to work on
* Decent compensation package (declining)
* No significant alternatives in San Diego
cons:
* Executive management doesn't seem to get the gravity of the situation or is doing a very poor job communicating to employees. For example, why are all they always trumping up great results and roadmap, but our stock is down 50% and financial results continue to reduce every quarter.
* Seems like the company is run by bean-counters instead of engineers. Intead of focus on innovation and R&D, meaningless cost-cutting measures reduce employees morale
* Salaries frozen for more than a year, no bonuses, health benefits reduced
* Many sharp folks are leaving the company, the rest and thinking about it

job_title: Senior Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Innovation is the key word at Qualcomm. We are motivated and rewarded heavily for innovation. I learn something new everyday. Qualcomm has a great reward program for new ideas by employees and the right ideas take very little time to get funded and converted to real world projects within Qualcomm.

QC also encourages a great work life balance. Numerous clubs inside the campus make sure that one is never short of activities. Team bonding events within groups are common place through out the year. 

Finally, we get free dinner Mon through Thursday. This is a gourmet three course dinner. Small things like this go a long way in making employees feel great about working in Qualcomm.
cons: Compensation is fair but could be higher. That is probably the only thing I would change about Qualcomm. Similar positions in other companies get compensated a whole lot more.

review_title: Restructure the pyramid, remove aging leadership
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Great company to learn a variety of skills, good job security so far. Compensation is good, insurance great, senior executives are wise industry leaders. Very hard working employees, amazing talent pool.
cons: Some divisions and projects are run poorly. Mid-management is rather weak, lack foresight and aging non-contributing managerial positions are leading a half checked out semi-retired life.

job_title: Senior Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
1. Great people (my team and teams that I work with). 
2. Good salary and benefit (until 2014). 
3. Beautiful city, perfect weather (San Diego)
cons:
1. Always busy, pressure and stress sometimes
2. Expensive life at San Diego
3. Very fast pace environment (almost no time to learn)
4. Layoff, bonus and salary reductions since 2014
5. Dealing with demanding customers
6. Crazy work hours (10am-7pm)

job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent Benefits, easy to gain experience even if you don't have any (careful this is also a con).
cons: Everything gets lost in translation.  Too many layers of management that don't have a clue about the technology below surface level.  Low talent gets put into high talent required positions because management doesn't know what makes a good engineer.  You can tell it's been a cycle of promoting unqualified people for over a decade.  As a software engineer in a hardware heavyweight industry, I recommend you stay away.  If you want a good software company to grow in, make sure you pick a team which understands what it takes to build good quality scalable extensible software.

job_title: Anonymous Employee
pros: Qualcomm had a good run when the smart phones and individual devices were on the boom.  Now it is changing.
cons: People show their true colors in crisis, and the same goes with the company.  Some of the junior and mid layer managers have been in the company just long enough that they cannot move up or out.  They are trying to cling on with *all* they have.  Their bosses sees what's happening but decides to turn a blind eye.  This has made it very difficult for the staff.  Because instead of empowering the staff to achieve their best performance, the staff are being used as pawns to grab more project, or show more results than the other manager.  The dotted line management and reporting structure has also made it confusing for the staff when support/help is needed.

review_title: Fast pace company with mediocre management
job_title: Senior Hardware Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: As one of the major suppliers to wireless industries, Qualcomm leads many IC designs in wireless, modem and also microprocessors. You can definitely learn a lot of skills and knowledge in the most up-to-date circuit design in this fast pace company. The benefit is really good--- you barely spend money in visiting doctors.
cons: Since the design pace is really fast, mangers will try very effort to push you even though the deadline is not feasible. Also the promotion is really political, if your manager does not like you, your promotion will be very slow no matter how hard that you work.

job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: High salary, good benefits, RSU's and bonus. Very good work environment with great facilities. Depending on title you will get an office. Cutting edge technology
cons: Very political. Politics is driven by the Indian mafia. Management has been promoted on the basis of race and technical ability alone. Ability to lead and manage people does not come into it. So the company has ended up with a lot of senior geeks and no leaders.

job_title: Software Engineering Intern in San Diego, CA
pros:
-Amazing intern events that include surfing lessons, hackathons, Servapalooza, summer on the lawn(QSOL) events, technical talks, laser tagging, carnivals, soccer tournaments, volleyball tournaments, movie nights, and much more
-the Campus Team is great and makes the internship really fun
-You get to work on ground-breaking projects that will change the future of mobile technology
-My team treated me as a valuable member of the team
-Got to push code on a weekly basis and my features were being used by other members of my team
-Get housed in a fully furnished, luxury apartment with maid service
-Live in sunny San Diego where there are tons of things to do during the weekends with your fellow interns
cons: - Like most tech companies, there is a lack of diversity. For example, the team that I was in did not have one female developer. However, recently, Qualcomm has made efforts to change this by holding conferences for diverse college candidates

review_title: Still a Great Company, But Not What it Used to Be
job_title: Director of Product Management in San Diego, CA
pros:
*Excellent Health Benefits (could be changing soon)
*Decent Comp. Plans
*Above-board, open-door corporate culture
*Talented co-workers and managers
*Tons of educational and knowledge expansion opportunities
cons:
*Nobody at the top layer leaves, so VERY limited upward mobility
*Office politics are worse than most
*Company getting increasingly stingy with options, RSUs, etc.
*Innovation and pushing the envelope not encouraged. Don't rock the boat
*Very "inside-out" development mentality which is typical of Engineering-focused companies ("I just built this cool widget, now let's figure out who wants to buy it.")

review_title: QCOM - Very challenging work, great benefits/bonuses, CRAZY LONG WORK HOURS IN QCT - A SWEATSHOP
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Challenging work, very professional staff, great benefits, industry leader, room to grow.
cons: If working in the largest division, QCT - (Qualcomm CDMA Technologies) - it's a SWEATSHOP, SWEATSHOP, SWEATSHOP...  expect 60+ hour weeks routine unless you are very good at pushing back.  That is why they are industry leader - they extract more output per employee than similar companies at the expense of the employee.

review_title: Good at execution. Bad at planning.
job_title: Staff Product Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: Qualcomm has an amazing engineering team that executes any product ahead of schedule every time, beating customer expectations always. Qualcomm is one of the most nimble large companies I have ever seen. Management can change course of the company on very short notice. It is like watching an ocean liner turn like a speed boat.
cons: Management's ill conceived product planning has resulted in the company squandering billions of dollars developing products (or acquiring companies for technologies and products) that nobody wants . This has led to awful ROI metrics for several programs leading to massive layoffs. The office environment has gotten toxic with people throwing their team members under the bus for self-preservation.

job_title: Software Engineer
pros:
- compensation is pretty good
- work/life balance is pretty good
- nice perks like a gym, health center, etc.
cons:
- it is a pretty soulless place to work (maybe not for all groups). You must enjoy doing tedious work, devoid of creativity. Most of the work involves logistics.
- the career progression culminates in a routine of meetings and power-point
- there are very few American engineers, which seems odd for an American location. Working there is like working in a foreign country, which is fun sometimes. But, it is difficult to not feel like an outsider as an American engineer. 
- there is very little diversity
- the culture is very passive aggressive.

review_title: Great technical work, but lots of pitfalls
job_title: Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Job Stability, San Diego ( can be good or bad), Good technical work if you are willing to work hard, Benefits
cons:
Salary: Was offered lower than some start ups. HR plays hardball and leaves no room for negotiation ended up getting 6k more than originally quoted. You tend to start off with unhappy employees. Bonuses are probably industry's lowest.

Team dynamics: Every group has its own kind of politics. Usually it will involve middle management, who does nothing but manage. Most of these people lack technical skills to remain in company, but due to extremely bad review process, they will linger on. 

Most of the middle management is content to manage up and give more work to people under them. So most of the engineers leave after 2-3 years. Bad talent sticks around.

review_title: Good place to work if you don't mind recycling other people's work
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Bridgewater, NJ
pros: Great benefits, flexible work environment. Immediate supervisor was terrific.
cons:
Middle management incompetent and flat out has no business being managers. One nearly caused me to burn out from overworking the team (EVERYTHING was an emergency because he wanted it done fast so he could look good).

Work consisted mostly of recycling code from other groups within Qualcomm - mostly in San Diego. No way to innovate! San Diego acts like their excrement smells sweeter than everybody else's and does not provide support or adequate documentation for their stuff.

No appreciation for past work by some senior engineering staff (not even a "thank you" when I left). I was never thanked by one manager even though he got a promotion thanks to my efforts and those of my colleagues.

job_title: Anonymous Employee
pros: Number 1 in mobile; office in San Diego; good company name on resume
cons:
Lots of politics 
Working bees easily do 10 hrs + a day, could spend up to 16 hrs a day in crunch time, when your boss hits the gym and do 9 to 5 everyday 
Compressed schedule and unrealistic 
Technically incompetent engineer somehow become your boss or lead
Incompetent lead would shield emails and meetings from working bees so only he will be on the spot light but expect you to know all the information needed to get the job done even though he doesn't share any info with you
Moving up is all about how well you talk not work 
Growth in general is super slow
Expect no promotion in 10 years if your boss or lead doesn't like you
Bottom line, would not recommend to friends

review_title: Do you like perks? sorry qualcomm doesn't have perks anymore
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Depending on the team you can work on challenging problems.
cons:
Reduced benefit is a real bummer. Health insurance is getting a huge downgrade in 2016.

Company is really cheap. why does procuring a new monitor need to go to VP of finance? why is it almost impossible to get a laptop upgrade when your current one clearly no longer functions well enough for the job? Compared to companies in Silicon valley where employees are pampered Qualcomm really doesn't give a damn about the people doing the work.

Company politics is a joke, incompetent people at management level with their equally incompetent lackeys getting all the promotions and raises while the good people are hardly recognized.

review_title: A good place to work - but only if you're based in San Diego
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Cambridge, England
pros:
. Good benefits package
. Reasonably flexible management
. Relaxed work environment
. Good opportunities for travel
. A very good infrastructure for software development and good support staff
cons:
The senior management have a very strong San-Diego focus.  If you're based outside of SD or, even worse, outside of the US get then you need to get used to being a second class corporate citizen.

The process for performance reviews is overly complicated,  and the reviews themselves tend not to be very useful - mostly a box ticking exercise with no real useful feedback.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefits are excellent, positions tend to be flexible, job growth is not forgotten, pay is good, plenty of non-work events, easy to get equipment, stable job (for the most part). Overall, great working environment.
cons: Qualcomm chipsets power a huge range of devices in the worldwide market. In order to stay competitive, the pipeline is always filled to the brim. This means that there's very little time for good software practices and much of the effort, at least from a SW perspective, is spent porting and patching. This gets tiresome after a while and doesn't provide for much satisfaction with one's job as actual innovation often needs to take a backseat. In addition, because there are so many engineers involved, getting things done is often difficult because there's always some team you'll need to get support from in order to get the job done, no matter how simple the task. The overhead is exhausting.

review_title: Android team is filled with smart, considerate people, but things suffer a bit from 'panic mode'
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Speaking only for Qualcomm Innovation Center, Qualcomm's Android arm:

The company atmosphere is encouraging and helpful, allowing relative freedom for individuals to pursue opportunities of their choice. Teams are small and tight knit and most work is done in labs to facilitate collaboration. There is little bureaucracy to get in the way of work. People are generally in a good mood and happy to accomplish things.
cons:
Having not quite shed its roots as a manufacturing company, Qualcomm suffers from a lack of documentation and testing practices. However this is improving (slowly).
Managers sometimes do not have time for their employees due to overtaxed schedules, and occasionally long hours will be required due to tight release schedules and continuous patching of poorly designed software.

review_title: Fat,old company trying to lose weight and find itself
job_title: IT Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: The best part right now is the people.  It's great working with smart, like-minded, and hard working individuals coming together to get projects done.  I have been working with pretty much the same people for over 6 years.
cons: The worst part right now is the people.  Company leadership seems lost. Very little guidance or direction for the future of the company. Very unsure of where the company is headed.  Department management is poor which causes chaos and unhappy employees. After recent layoffs, it's definitely a very different company!  No pay raises and change in medical adds to the tough times now.

review_title: Started off great & make sure you're in the right department
job_title: Accountant in San Diego, CA
pros: Company WAS incredibly generous. Provided incredible benefits and all the bells & whistles that came with working for a large company.
cons: The company took a different direction that no longer valued it's employees (if you're not part of the legal or engineering department, I was in finance). The finance department was built from a group of friends that recruited one another. Whether you were a good employee or not, did not matter to management. They stood by who could kiss butt and who their friends were.

job_title: Senior Design Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work-life balance at entry-level.  You get to work with the best of the best when it comes to IC design. Work hours are reasonable, and I rarely see anyone being too stressed about work hours at least in IC design team.
cons:
As you become more senior and lead a project, you need to have meetings with other parts of the world and often times, this means meeting at 10 pm. Also, the amount of meetings that managers have is often quite a lot which led many senior staff level engineers to quit and move to other companies.

Also, total compensation package is not very competitive compared to the competitors. This also often causes staff and senior staff engineers to quit and seek for better compensation.

Overall, a great company to learn the trade then move onto the better paying company.

review_title: Qualcomm is still an inexperienced company
job_title: Dsa in San Diego, CA
pros: If you are a engineer you are treated like God. If you are not you are not valued.
cons: Discrimination, unfair, favoritism, HR is a joke and helps no one. Incompetent leaders and managers.

review_title: Qualcomm is GREAT if you happen to be in San Diego - anywhere else, you're an afterthought.
job_title: Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: The office atmosphere is very nice. Everyone gets an office with a door that closes. The people are generally vital and energetic, and as a result there is a very positive energy throughout the company.
cons: If you're not in San Diego you are a very 2nd class citizen of the company. Benefits are all keyed to San Diego. Do a good job? Here's a coupon for a spa in San Diego. Oh, you live in Portland? Too bad. But hey, here's a perk... a "passport card" that gets you discounts at 1000s of San Diego area merchants, shops, and restaurants!

review_title: A technical leader in the industry with abundant resources for learning and talented skillful employees.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: As Qualcomm is a strong technical leader in the industry, you surely can learn a lot by working here. In general Qualcomm employees are very technical and confident. They are also easily accessible and are willing to discuss technical problems with their colleagues. Location-wise San Diego is definitely a great place to live. It was an enjoyable experience as an intern at Qualcomm.
cons: The major products of Qualcomm are cellphone chips. They seem to put more emphasis on hardware and systems than software. As a software developer you are probably not going to receive as much attention as system designer. Also the company is pretty large with so many talented employees. It's maybe pretty difficult to climb up the ladder in such an organization.

review_title: A good place to work, but tough
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Good compensation and benefits (for now); generally friendly people that are easy to work with; can work on cutting-edge technology and for an industry leader;  high retention rate, few people leave because this is considered the pinnacle of many fields;   an environment that can have a grad-school feel at times (to a point, see:  upcoming layoffs);
cons: Crunch-time is the default state, expect to work evenings and weekends often, which will get worse with the hiring freeze;  benefits and stock grants to be cut;  rising is slow due to people entrenched in the top positions

job_title: Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: You get to live in San Diego while working for tech, but otherwise, not much else going for it these days
cons:
Outdated technology (e.g. Office 2013).

No choice in laptops (must be HP/ThinkPad) and even new hires are given recycled laptops.

Benefits aren't great anymore. Health benefits are still paid for, but if you need to do any sort of medical procedure, be ready to pay out of pocket until you hit the deductible.

No sense of brand ambassador. Management makes complaints about a certain company's phone line cutting into our profits, yet an entire row of employees is using that company's phones.

Talent pool is dry, people don't want to work at/for Qualcomm, so all the new hires are essentially leftovers from other hiring pools.

Work/life balance is a myth here, does not exist. Manager is constantly complaining about staying at work until 9-10pm as if they're hinting they want us to stay with them.

Middle management doesn't know how to manage, all about shmoozing to get that next promotion.

review_title: Poor senior management, onerous open source processes, process heavy
job_title: Principal Software Engineer
pros:
Your experience may vary widely by division, but in general some things are done well:
Automatic header files from RTL
Capital expenditure for HW, SW, FPGA emulation
Automatic build, boot, some CI infrastructure
cons:
QCT specially is very process heavy
QC just lost its entire custom CPU core team after they bungled the Datacenter division: huge blunder for a chip company to lose its entire custom CPU team.. bleeding talent right now
Core teams do work, and then there are root teams per customer
A lot of QCT firmware teams don't like to adopt standards/open source software
Linux development is very process heavy with small things needing legal approval
Management was great under founders, but progressively losing its way: current "leaders" are in panic mode and if they go down route of 30 billion dollars buy backs, that's the beginning of the end
Even after layoffs, still a lot of fat in SD, lots of layers of mgmt, too many status collectors

review_title: Qualcomm is a large, but smoothly running organization.
job_title: Staff Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Qualcomm is a large, but smoothly running organization.  Management has a very progressive outlook on wireless technology and is not adverse to trying new ideas.  As an individual engineer, you and your work are respected.  Projects are not 'overcrowded' and 90% of engineers have their own office.  Also, the company realizes that the most talented engineers have the option of working elsewhere.  For that reason performance reviews occur once every 6 months.   The average raise is 3 - 5% (every 6 months!).  It is common for engineers to move around within the organization.  The company provides a mechanism for new learning and for movement to different areas of the technology.
cons: The company is essentially a massive IP portfolio that covers many different areas of technology.  Occasionally one can feel disconnected from the rest of the organization.

review_title: An amazing place to work.  No place is perfect, but this is about as close as it gets.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: A focus on the employee and the quality of their life while at work and at home.  Excellent benefits, great services at work - health clinic, gym, etc. Movies shown in company theater.  Ceremony for veteran's day.  Paul Jacobs was a very engaged CEO.  Would talk to any employee.  Would see him in meetings with all levels of employee.  He loved getting his hands dirty with the engineers.  Tons of respect for him.
cons: Very much an engineering culture.  If you aren't an engineer you can be made to feel stupid.  Hard culture ot break into.  Many people have worked there for their entire career.

review_title: Good things to learn but with lot of pressure.
job_title: Software Developer in Hyderābād
pros:
1. You can learn technology if you want, no matter in which team you are.
2. There may be times to implement new things but it comes very rare and it depends on team and technology for which you work.
3. Very open culture with respect to timings.
4. Work from home option available.
cons:
1. In the name of development mainly debugging takes place.
2. Due to cost cutting salary review is decreased from 2 times a year to 1 time and salary hike is also decreased than before.
3. You may be called on weekends any time, as you are provided with laptops. You are expected to check mails even on weekends.
4. Employees are expected to work late nights. So, there are long working hours and over pressure.

job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: Great minds and innovation oriented company. They reward patents and ideas. Good 401k matching in the industry and great healthcare benefits.
cons: Retaining all the top management with hefty pays and stocks, while laying off the bottom level engineers, who does the real work,  is going to get them nowhere. Multiple mis-steps from management has driven the company to a ditch. The worst part is,  the management keeps blaming the customers' competition,  the cost of production, and the customer itself for their misgivings. The timing of all these seems impeccable, as it all began with the new CEO. The layoff seems to be a dance to the investors' charm. No more care for their employees. Things only happen by stock prices. Some benefits, including health insurance have been re-structured.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Andover, MA
pros:
Best benefits ever, employees pay nothing out of pocket, yes I said nothing. Salary is great depending on the where you are coming from, meaning I think most would rate salary well, but you have a few who were paid really well before joining Qualcomm and may feel differently. 

Work/life is good depending on your manager, mine was great but have heard others complain their manager was not so easy to deal with when trying to get time off. Potential to move up is good with a company this large, great college reimbursement.
cons: Too busy to allow employee growth, many many resources and learning opportunities available but no time to take advantage of them, such as Qualcomm provided online/on site classes. Management is not that organized, promised grooming for promotion never came about.

review_title: not a good place to work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: i dont see anything that you wont find elsewhere. only pro i can think of is you have a job and you are getting paid regularly
cons: not sure about other teams but for us, no innovation, no scope to learn anything. doesnt add any value to your resume. no proper channel to assign work (work doesnt get assigned by your lead. anyone with an equal or higher title can walk up to your desk and dump work on you and your lead will be totally in the dark). about  more than 95% of the work is unnecessary and can be automated. matrix management system is the worst way to review an engineer. the manager drafting your performance review has no interaction with you on a daily basis. a week before the review, you will be asked to summarize everything you worked on during the last review period. this causes many people to spend 10% of their time working and 90% of their time projecting their work and making sure  everyone THINKS he/she works too hard. the perfect recipe for disaster

job_title: Legal Specialist
pros: Insurance premiums are paid for you and your family.  401k match is pretty good.   Vacation plans are good.
cons: Workload is totally overwhelming.  Benefits have really decreased in last few years.     Reviews and salary increases are now only once a year and are very low.  The last two cutbacks have more than doubled our workloads.  No approved overtime, but work has increased.   Used to be a wonderful place to work and you felt so appreciated and valued.  No longer.   No balance of work and family life.   Morale for entire IP department is rock bottom.  Most of us are looking elsewhere.  Quality of work will be declining due to increased workloads.

review_title: A great company needs a little name recognition
job_title: HR Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Creativity and enthusiasm of employees. Working at Qualcomm is exciting, and there is always an opportunity to make a contribution. Excellent benefits and workplace activities add a sense of fun to the workplace and employee involvement in company culture is encouraged and strongly supported by management.
cons: There is still an eight to five vibe within the corporate realm, and there's not as much openness to telecommuting as there could be. Salaries are a little lower than in other companies. Otherwise, there are few downsides.

job_title: Recruiter in San Diego, CA
pros: When given the choice between designing the brain or the body, Qualcomm CDMA Technologies, a.k.a. QCT, chose to design the brain.  As a result, Qualcomm and QCT design hardware and software for every discipline and standard imaginable; CDMA, WCDMA, BREW, video, audio, displays, etc.  QCT is a meritocracy and the system is designed to give equal access to opportunities to both current and potential employees.
cons: Hard to call it a direct criticism of QCT, but the communication semiconductor business is hyper competitive on an international level and there is relentless market pressure to reduce margins.  To make a good ROI you have to be in front of the competition with novel products/services that capture a premium.  There is also little brand awareness outside the industry, making semiconductor companies, in general, subject to nearly continual treadmill-like activity that can sometimes seem like a race with out a finish line.

review_title: Qualcomm very good place to start career
job_title: Principal Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: good for starting a career for software engineers. work for 2 to 3 years you'll learn a lot and after that you do well if you are a superstar category. If you like to write software which sits very close to the hardware then this is a great place for you. It is also great place if you want to work in research (RF, modem, wireless) as qc puts $1billion+ in R&D every year.
cons: In software groups, moving up on the ladder is through curve fitting like min 3+ years in title unless you are a super star. work-life balance is not a focus at  lower titles. San diego is not a great place for software jobs so your best buddies from past years may not be around to hangout with you. If you don't care much for those friends and fully driven by work then Qualcomm is the place for you.

review_title: Great place to work, could be the greatest with some changes!
job_title: VP, Engineering in San Diego, CA
pros:
. Fast pace of work and broad technology innovation, honest/upright executive management.
. Opportunity to do business with with a rich set of customers worldwide.
. Great set of talented employees worldwide who are willing to learn and contribute.
. Among non-management employees - open atmosphere, constructive criticism is encouraged
cons:
. Virtually 24-hour work cycle due to dense product roadmap and worldwide customer base.
. Difficulty of commercializing new technologies is often underestimated
. Product lifecycle is not managed as effectively as it can be: e.g. new products are added without considering the sustained/continued growth of existing products (and resources required for sustaining vs. designing new products).
. Hardware and Software leverage from existing products can be improved considerably.

review_title: Qualcomm as a new CS graduate employer
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Employees work on a wide range of cutting-edge technologies and are able to learn many exciting skills if they want to learn. Due to explosion of mobile industry, there are many opportunities in the company and it has grow more than 50% over past few years
cons: Long hours and lack of work-life balance. The industry is super competitive and company/departments need to work very hard to develop new technologies and maintain existing ones. Late night and weekend work is quite common in most departments. Salary is not competitive compare to other large companies in the industry, so many good people left to join companies like Apple, Amazon, etc. There are still many dead woods in the firm and don't seem to contribute much to company's bottom line, except creating more meetings for people around them.

review_title: Smart people, good values, but too much hierarchy and a LOT of work
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Lot of smart people willing to collaborate.  Projects move at fast pace. Decisions are usually fast unless it is across divisions.  Top Management is strategic, open, and no (known) scandals. Many top people are also easy to approach to.  Lots of perks and some fun activities (if you have time to participate)
cons: Lot of hierarchy - too many directors/sr. directors etc. Earlier it was engineer heavy company, now it is is heavy management.  This limits internal growth tremendously.  Also unless some top management likes you, there is little scope for advancement.   Work/life balance is only on the paper - some projects have insane work schedules and email floods your inbox and you are expected to respond "ASAP".

review_title: Qualcomm is a great place to work
job_title: Associate Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
1. Get to work on the latest technology
2. Good compensation
3. Good knowledge base, you will be working with the team who knows about the IP end to end, if lucky with the original designers
4. Food, cafeteria, team outing, nice office buiding, gym, year-end gifts etc
cons:
1. Work-life balance, there will be tons of works. I guess good compensation comes at the cost of this huge workload
2. The learning and exploration are on your own, you can't expect any training/hand holding. You have to be responsible for your own learning and ramp up. At times you'll have to work while ramping up, you'll have to work extra hours during that time.
3. Expect to work from day one.

review_title: For interns a very good place to work!
job_title: Interim Engineering in San Diego, CA
pros:
Nice City; everything on location; food; sport; work; provides housing for interns!!
You can work on state of the art. Interns get research jobs (with the right supervisor).
cons:
none so far, but I am only an intern and don't have a lot to compare it too. I guess a lot depends on your job, your supervisor and the group. 

The intern program could also integrated some ... training...for example have a main job, but go to another dept or do something else too. A circuit designer could go to work a week or two for the layout and testing team. This way the itnern meets more people and learns about issues from the other site which he didn't consider before.

review_title: Great company overall, good benefits, safe bet for now
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros:
Compensation package is good overall.
Benefits are great especially for higher titles. 
Secure company for now, great market position.
cons:
Benefits have some oddities... E.g. negotiated benefits would pay for adoption fees, but nothing for IVF or other infertility treatments which are typically covered to some extent in similar size companies.
Work/life balance can easily suffer in San diego with very aggressive schedules, over the last a few years schedules have become increasingly unreasonable.
Hiring in SD is too lax imho... There is some good talent but a lot of incompetence in some groups. The case is much better in regional offices where every req is scarce and scrutinized.

review_title: Great Company for Engineering Work and Growth
job_title: Staff Engineer
pros: Great support for practicing world-class engineering (library, tools, etc.)  plus great support for healthy living (on-site clinic, gyms, healthy food, sick days as needed, etc), work-life balance, and community support (volunteering, charity contribution support, etc).  Great campus environment (farmers market, festivals, fairs, etc).  Great learning opportunities (courses on-campus, streamed, and/or on-demand are available).
cons: It is a big company in a very competitive and rapidly changing industry.  You have to be and stay on top of your game. Qualcomm gives you plenty of support but you have to deliver.  You also have to put some effort to find the right fit for your skills or grow into a new position/role as projects and/or goals change.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Toronto, ON
pros:
1 good pay, benefit
2 product has high market share
cons:
1 They focus on deadline not the design. They didn't design right in the beginning and keep missing deadline, which will bring lots of pressure to everyone.
2 They cannot or don't want to keep experienced people. When you want to ask a question, nobody know the answer and they just CC around the email. If a person get green card, he will leave the company right away in silicon valley.
3 Company politics are involved everywhere. Every 6 months, they will start organization restructuring. I didn't know who is the boss of my director, as this person keeps changing.
4 They outsource lots of jobs to India, where it turned out some project had failed.

review_title: People who work the most are not rewarded
job_title: Staff Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: Qualcomm offers a very good environment for work. If you want to learn, it is a good place.
cons: Once management realizes that you work hard and are eager to contribute and excel in your career, they will not promote you but will instead keep you in your current level with a hanging bait that you need to do more to get to that next level you deserve for a long time. There are many people on higher levels who don't work nearly half as much as you do, yet they continue to get promotions and are paid 2x more. That is why this company is not going to last long.

review_title: Qualcomm wants to be market leader in whatever it does !!
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Excellent people to work with. No mid layer management crap. All people at senior levels have risen through the ranks.
Excellent benefits for entire family. Perhaps the best in US!!
cons:
Employers in Bay Area pay atleast 10% more than what Qualcomm offers in San Diego. It is high time salary correction is made for San Diego employees since the cost of living at San Diego is similar to that of Bay Area.

On a few days, work can get crazy and I end up staying long hours to finish it up...This perhaps is part of Qualcomm culture to give what it takes to keep customers happy!!

Also, it is common to work during weekends, if you are in town

job_title: Systems Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: The salary is good and the company is in San Diego.
cons:
It's a company of little fiefdoms, where people in different fiefdoms are seen as the enemy, and usually you are expected to not cooperate with them. The communication culture is horrible; not only do people not respond to emails within a day or two, they often don't respond at all, or will only respond if you cc a director or VP. Very little gets done without it being escalated to a director or VP, and even requests for people to just do their jobs are included in that. The politics are petty and destructive, but it's difficult to survive and impossible to advance without participating in the politics. 

While these cons have been around for a while, as the stock price drops, these cons get worse and the atmosphere gets gloomier and gloomier. Hopefully the past couple of days will help.

job_title: Technical Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: - Great people, laid back community and most of the work is done in San Diego.  The people that work there are some of the nicest and most humble people you will meet. They have a big sense of community and it's fairly common for them to be friends outside of work as well and go on family vacations together.
cons: - Company has too many folks that joined 20+ years ago and know only the Qualcomm way of doing things.  Think of it as hero ball culture, my way or the highway...  One of the big reasons that Qualcomm is not doing too well these days.

job_title: Support Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Most co-workers are friendly. Very flexible schedules. Performance review process is simpler than most places I've worked and lets you give your input. Lots of on-the-job training for RF engineering. Much does depend on which department you are in also. I'm basing on my department and the ones I interacted with.
cons: Lots of tribalism and territorialism. You will be taught, but not too much if it threatens someone's turf. High percentage of H1B worker and American citizens seem to be in a small minority. Rational is still given that it's because of a shortage of engineers in the USA, yet they have multiple layoffs.

review_title: Worst company you can work for!
job_title: Senior Engineer in Hyderābād
pros: Salary is the only pro here, nothing else is good about this company. Please avoid this company if you want some work life balance.
cons:
No sense of work life balance.
Forced to work for extra hours without recognition.
Extremely poor management, first and second level managers have no managerial skills at all.
Boot licking culture is prevalent.
No recognition or appreciation for an employee even though that employee is working beyond his capacity. 
No regard for health or personal issues of employee.
If you give an honest negative feedback for anybody, this will not remain anonymous and will come back and and bite you. Why take feedback if nobody wants to improve.
Work practices are too slow and inter team dependency will further slowdown your work progress, but this will be counted as a negative point for you no matter what.
If you ask for a particular kind of work/team, a straight 'no' is the answer from management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee
pros: Great as long as you are part of the execution team and not being given insane deadlines with no support to achieve them.  Great salary range, lots of interesting work to be done.
cons: The recent pressure to make the chips a commodity is going to be a huge challenge.  The growth of the company has many possible paths but as of now it is cutting staff which makes career growth a challenge too.

job_title: Recruiter in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm has hired, with few exceptions, extremely talented people who are also easy to work with and continues to be able to attract the best and brightest.  The standards at the company are very high and all of the facilities are what you would expect of a market leader, including well managed cafeterias, fitness facilities and reverse osmosis drinking water in every break room, which is a small detail but that says a lot about the people that have made this company what it is.
cons: It's a fast paced work environment and we tend to run a little lean which is good if you like to stay busy but can sometimes feel like a drag when even taking one day off results in having to cram the next 2 days into 1.

job_title: RF Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: A leader in commercial telecommunications. Initially, Qualcomm really took care of its employees and gave them means to develop their skills. Qualcomm offered very competitive salary, health benefits, and on-the-job training.
cons:
In my opinion, Qualcomm is lagging in the innovation field. At the will of its investors, Qualcomm relies on making its majority revenue from selling its top-tier chips. Consequently, its hard to propose an R&D project that falls outside the scope of selling its integrated solutions without it being shot down.

Work-life balance is skewed towards work

Recent layoffs were handled poorly

review_title: Qualcomm is an overall good company to work for, just make sure you end up in the right group...
job_title: Intern in San Diego, CA
pros: The company offers good benefits, and a good compensation. The people are nice and the working atmosphere is pleasant. Qualcomm likes to emphasize on balancing work life and hobbies. There are nice events organized for employees. I think it is a great place to work for when you have a family. Your working hours are also very flexible.
cons: Big company, can feel lost sometimes as an intern. I worked in two different groups. I hated the first one but really liked the second one. Your experience depends a LOT on your group (and therefore your manager too). I did not learn much in my first group but learned a lot in my second group in a shorter period of time.

job_title: Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
Most of my team is smart and nice to work with.
Traffic in Mira Mesa is only a problem for about half an hour in the morning and an hour in the evening, and, if you dodge that window, it's a quick commute to the various housing around.
cons:
If you don't like cubicles, well, all future space is looking likely to be cubicles.
Housing is almost as expensive as San Francisco.
There is an enormous amount of paperwork surrounding checking in changes.
There are just enough people who make just enough noise and don't seem to understand stuff that one can be left with the feeling of working with idiots even when almost everyone is nice to deal with.
Qualcomm is currently trying to reduce staffing costs, so you're pretty much stuck wherever you are.

job_title: Staff Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Opportunity to work on new technology.
I had several good supervisors.
cons:
There were a lot of managers who were technically smart, but not good at managing people or projects. There were a few managers who displayed amazing immaturity. I could not believe they were in positions of authority.

Qualcomm executive management seemed to have "magical thinking" about the company's ability to overcome technical challenges and make things work. Sometimes having smart employees is not enough. They spent vast sums on my projects over 5 years, but everything wound up in the trash can.

The "Internal Opportunity System" (aka IOS...the system to apply to different jobs within Qualcomm) is broken.

job_title: Senior Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm was built and flourished based on respect for each and every employee, granting individual autonomy and removing barriers when encountered, and promoting a work hard, play hard culture.  These simple corporate cultural traits enabled advancements in wireless technology to flourish.
cons: Qualcomm leadership has lost its way; they are disjointed and not aligned.  WHat was once and engineering driven company is now run by finance and legal opportunists - where once ingenuity and thoughtful risk was encouraged and rewarded, today predictability and short term results (at any costs to employee sacrifice) is rewarded.  Employees are paranoid and waiting for their ax to drop, resulting in no loyalty and lost synergy across the enterprise.

job_title: IT Staff Systems and Security Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Qualcomm has a great and diverse culture that makes it easy to work with and collaborate well with others.  There are numerous avenues for training opportunities as well.  Here we are able to work with cutting edge technology and ideas as well as given some leniency with thinking outside the box for solutions.
cons: With the recent layoffs and belt-tightening going around, the benefits have been reduced, along with the workforce.  As one person said the other day, the "golden handcuffs" have come off.  Advancement opportunities for mid-level people are stale to non-existent.

review_title: Qualcomm A Great Place to Work
job_title: N/A
pros: Qualcomm has great flexibility.  In general the benefits (including fringe benefits like 401K match, having a gym, etc.) are great and the people are wonderful to work with.  As with all big companies, depends totally on the team you are in, but in general Qualcomm has a very enjoyable work environment.  As long as you are productive and get your work done, they let you decide how to go about doing it.
cons: It suffers from many of the challenges that other large companies suffer from.  Achieving a balance between consistent processes and flexibility.  In addition it faces some major business challenges in the near future.

review_title: Traditional environment, Good people, Interesting work
job_title: Staff Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros: Qualcomm invests in creating new things, so there are lots of opportunities to create. The environment is what I would call "traditional corporate". You don't have free lunches or on-site massage like the dot coms, but you do have private offices with doors that can close!
cons: The drawback is that Qualcomm best understands radio, and the modem-side of the house gets all the love. If you're on another technology and thongs are going well then you'll be supported. However, when tightening hits it will be your project on the block because the radio is where it's at.

review_title: Qualcomm - strives for greatness in San Diego.
job_title: Staffing Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Great group of people to work with, both as peers and in management. Qualcomm seems to treat ALL of their employees with respect no matter their position or title within the company. Surrounded by the BEST engineering minds in the United States, if not the world. Incredible benefits, continued technology education and good work life balance. They also look to employees for constant feedback on how to improve and stay on top of our industry.
cons: Salaries could be improved upon to help with the high cost of living in San Diego.

review_title: 11 on forbes best places to work at?!! NOT!
job_title: Senior Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: If you want to get engineering experience, this is a great place to be because Qualcomm does venture into every new wireless product available. Also, it is easy to approach experts in different areas and get one's technical curiosities satisfied.
cons: The company culture is of workhorses, people literally seem to be working like crazy for no good reason. The prioritization of everything is always "critical", and it need not be. Easy to feel burnt out or sitting among robots. Not much scope for growth if you want to rise up quick. The review system does not really give much insight into rewards for job well done. The immigration system sucks so don't event thing about joining if you need a green card or something.

job_title: Database Administrator in San Diego, CA
pros: Fast moving, interesting work.  Lots of leading-edge technology in the database realm.  Great resources, training, contracted vendor experts (dedicated support engineers).  Truly a world class IT organization.  Really excellent place to grow your skills. Good salary and benefits.  Really smart people and good managers at the lower end.  Treated me very, very well for 15 years until I got laid off and then they treaded me even better in the transition out.  No complaints.  Just sad to go.
cons:
Unfortunately as with all companies moving from the entrepreneurial phase to older, more established phase, some bureaucracy is creeping in.   Lot's of night and weekend work.  But then they were always very fair in terms of compensation and adjustments of work time and location.

Company is struggling in the marketplace right now.  Hence the RIF that I was caught up in.

review_title: Did Qualcomm grow too big too fast?
job_title: Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Good work/life balance is definitely achievable, at least where I was.
- Working with great people who care about a quality product.
- Moved from matrix style managers to direct report managers. 
- Lots of interesting problems to solve.
cons:
- Work culture has taken a big hit recently with various layoffs and lawsuits
- Has grown into somewhat of a monolithic software company that moves slowly internally.  Also, a lot of the internal tools and processes are outdated or unrefined.
- The communication and collaboration between different teams is abysmal. 
- Benefits package getting worse every year.

job_title: Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Very good work/life balance. Health Benefits are good. Some of the new groups have opportunities for growth. San Diego weather is awesome. If you want to join QCOM, look for groups working on emerging technologies.
cons: Extremely challenging work environment with less career growth opportunities especially those working in very old departments in Qualcomm. Newer Technology group have good growth opportunities.  Each department/ divisions have their own rules in terms of appraisals and promotions. Development and Core group employees have least career growth possible, Some Day this division will see high attritions. May be the senior management is greedy so they keep all the bonuses and promotions for themselves. Juniors Engineers are the worst hit.

review_title: Good company, good compensation, good work, could do better people organization.
job_title: Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
The company has Flexible hours, so it makes it easy to do the work whenever you want to.
The compensation includes also Good package, which includes a good salary and health care.
The work is also interesting, as you are always working on new technologies which are yet to come out.
There is also strong encouragement to enhance your techie-skills. They have monthly classes on the hot communication topics which allow you to learn and keep up-to-date with  whats going on.
Qualcomm also organizes various events every now and then such as "Summer on the Lawn". Also, being in San Diego, the weather is always awesome and always a ball to hang out on the weekends.
cons: Unforeseen issues that come up and have to solved immediately

review_title: Qualcomm is a great place to work but there is room for improvement
job_title: Director in San Diego, CA
pros:
1. san diego is a great place to live
2. leader worldwide in wireless technology...driving the direction of tomorrow's wireless world 
3.  very interesting work.
4. smart engineers
cons:
1. engineers dont always make good managers
2. lack of vision for the company as a whole, as well as the divisions
3. lack of communication and cooperation and alignment across divisions

review_title: A great place for an engineering internship
job_title: Interim Engineering Intern in San Diego, CA
pros:
The people are great.  I loved striking up conversations with just about anybody.  You're surrounded by incredibly intelligent individuals, and you can learn a lot from normal conversation.  I had a relatively challenging project and I was able to see the final product before I left.

Also, San Diego is amazing, I can't think of a better place to live.
cons:
Sometimes people in other departments didn't do their job and it help up my project.  There is some bureaucracy, thought significantly less than other companies I have interned with.

Honestly, the worst part about the whole thing is having to leave.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros: The company has some great programs to help employees advance their own skill sets.  The benefits package is nice but is not that much better than other major firms.
cons: The review process is a joke.  It happens twice a year and is just a way for employees to bash each other anonymously.   Management would rather pit workers against each other than actually manage their employees.  Expect a management re-org at least every three months.  Execution of any idea there is almost non-existent.  It may have been a good company at one point but it's definitely going down the tubes.  For proof of that look at their stock price.

review_title: Interesting work, long working hours, high pressure to deliver, stupid policies.
job_title: Anonymous Employee
pros:
Some really smart people work here.
friendly work atmosphere.
challenging and interesting work.
good insight into the industry.
cons:
super tight deadlines
high pressure to deliver
stupid policies that makes no sense 
(latest ridiculous policy, you can choose to have either a desktop or a laptop, not both. Not even if you already have both but the laptop is 5+ years old and need to be replaced)
Pay less than other top engineering companies.
no culture. everyone here is work work work.

job_title: Staff IT Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: The biggest benefit Qualcomm has given me is its San Diego location.  Other than that, good points are that it's a large employer, has good benefits, and offers a competitive salary and stock programs.
cons: Corporate "strategic realignment" has meant lots of lost jobs.  It's a shame, given Qualcomm's history of being a stable employer.  The environment has drastically changed in the 8+ years that I have been a Qualcomm employee: from warm and fuzzy to cold and corporate.  It's truly tragic knowing that so many are losing their jobs to overseas/nearshore folks when Qualcomm has billions in the bank, but MBAs are steering the ship these days.

review_title: Great company if you need job for life
job_title: Financial Analyst in London, England
pros: Really good work life balance, Management are really supportive, RSU and ESPP options, other benefits
cons:
As any other large blue chip company, your basic salary will be much lower as Brand name attracts many strong candidates,
All people live in their feel good bubble created by company with 20% less salary then of their potential in market.
Growing up the ladder is really difficult in the company, due to lots bureaucracy. The rating system , no of years in positions etc etc before you could jump, lots of box ticking. For IT/Engineers and Senior management this company is great but for support function staff its not the best lets stay unless you want some place for 9 to 5 without challenge and growth.

review_title: Great company, but the increasingly 'Indian' work-culture may be its undoing.
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Generous to employees. Great corporate policies. Mindful of ethics. Lots of freedom for employees. Overall, the official corporate stance 'Innovate, Execute & Partner' is awesome.
cons: Excessive email volume. Multi-tasking is encouraged (and seems to be an excuse for not planning). More than 80% of Saturdays turn out to be working days - mostly to please and service Asian customers. Too much work-load. Frequent sparse work-load stretched over 12 hour days. Most jobs require 24-hour support with a 12-hour shift handled from India which needs untimely conference calls for tracking. All the cons come from a largely Indian mindset, temperament and work-culture.

job_title: Senior Staff Tech Writer in San Diego, CA
pros: Salary remains good for the San Diego area and the benefits are decent, but declining (health plan eroding, 401K fees enacted, etc.). Better than usual vacation benefit. Depending on the team (not department) you are in, management can be responsive and supportive but this is lessening due to employee and cost cutting, and overall company atmosphere.
cons: In the twelve years I've been at the Q, the job and company have gone from great to pretty dismal. When I started,  work/life balance was recognized and quality output was the priority. Over the years, the workload and deadlines have gone from normal for the industry to ridiculous. On my team, layoffs and ever-increasing workloads with impossible (if you want to produce quality) deadlines combined with team-wide confusion about any and all of the increasingly complicated processes makes it tough to do good work. The stress level has gone from manageable to toxic, all while employees should always have smiling faces - very emperor's new clothes environment.

review_title: Qualcomm a good place to work if not the best.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Company is doing well. It always is good to be a part of a company especially  if it is growing. I have been involved in 2 start-ups. I know the perils of an unstable work-place.
- One of the best places to learn technology across a broad spectrum.
- Good benefits.
cons:
- Company is growing into a big organization but behaves like a mid-sized company especially the middle management.
- Work load and stress a bit elevated.
- Some more compensation should be given because of the stress in the job.
- Does not pay for MBA if you are in a technical position.

review_title: Was a great place to work... but it is going down hill.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Boulder, CO
pros:
Good pay.  
Good Benefits (although they are getting worse over time).
You work with really smart people.
cons:
They just announced 15% work force reduction (layoffs).
Politics, Politics, Politics.  If you want to get promoted you need to learn to play the political game very early. 
Culturally the company is stuck in it's old ways.  There was always a focus on "out executing the competition."  This sounds good on paper but results in a lot of short cuts and TONS of technical debt in both HW and SW.  This leads to further band-aids/hacks which just perpetuates the core issues.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Access to latest technology, at my level, work with some really great people, still making a decent salary.
cons: Since the hostile takeover of Jana Partners, the focus of management has been on cost reduction, which can otherwise be read as value reduction.  This is a race to the bottom.  The best and brightest who can afford to leave, are.  Qualcomm was in the Fortune top 20 companies to work for a few years ago.  Now they're not in the top 100.  I have to ask myself why?

job_title: Senior Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
Engineering teams can be filled with great and friendly people. Like at most jobs, your experience will depend on your team.

For the most part, there's a good work/life balance. Working 9-5 and sometimes 9-6 is typical.
cons:
* Major layoffs in 2015 and again in 2018. I survived both but it makes you question the leadership.
* Stock price is less now than when I started 3 years ago and the outlook is not great. This is at a time when the stock market, and tech stocks specifically, are soaring. Negotiate your sign-on bonus in cash so it doesn't lose value before vesting.
* There is no company culture. Leadership doesn't instill any values or motivation. The CEO only ever says "we are going to be the leaders in 5G".

review_title: Great place to work, good benefits
job_title: Business Process Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros:
-Great benefits, including full health/dental
-Tuition reimbursement (if related to your job)
-Bonus structure
-Stock plan
-401k matching
-Clear management goals, good structure to the company
-Well-defined roles
-Internal inovation process where you can submit new product ideas.
cons:
-The roles can be too narrow if you are a jack-of-all-trades
-Stock upside isn't what it used to be
-Hard to advance up the ladder quickly

review_title: Not what it used to be - 20+ year employee review
job_title: Staff Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
In the beginning this was a fun, exciting, rewarding and fulfilling place to work; there is something to be said about being on the ground floor of innovation.  For true creative minds, being involved in the development and production of cutting edge technology is the ultimate "job".  For the first half of my life at Q, I didn't consider it a "job", it was a journey.  In the later years, it turned into a job.  As the company grew, so did management and egos, so did time lines and stress levels.  

Qualcomm went from being the leader on the table to a feeling of always being behind the 8-ball.  Hard for some of us old timers to adjust to - this is true.  Bring in the new, young, fresh blood to pick it up - I get that and see that it should happen.  But....  all of the innovation, bright minds, creativity, inventive vibe dissipates with each new wave of fresh blood brought in.  HR stopped hiring creative, intelligent souls and hand picked what I now call place holders.  Working the numbers game, tightening the reigns or nooses if you care to view it that way.    I have no qualms with the HR dept, never once in my 20+ years of working there did I ever speak to an HR rep for any reason.  I trusted and worked with my supervisor/manager.  But I always had the distinct impression teams like HR were only out for themselves or other agendas.  I honestly can not remember the number of managers I had (more than 10) but every single one of them said the same thing - don't involve HR if you don't have to.   Telling stuff right there.

Pros - there are good people there, they still have a chance at getting back to being an innovative company, bring in the creative minds who will create the next big thing.
cons:
Management, red tape, deadlines, I have an interesting take on "work-life balance".  For a time, I was working in a lab, part of a team helping to create a new technology.  We worked 6,sometimes 7 days a week, 10-12 hours a day and I loved it.  Why?  Because I was part of something fun and cutting edge.  Fast forward several years where I was in a sustaining role, working your basic 9-5, 5 days/week.  Longest days of my life.  Good managers and good HR personnel recognize where and how to place their talent.  

Somewhere along the way this went out the window.  Did anyone notice how happy I was and how much I excelled in my job when I was basically LIVING at work?  Did anyone notice how my reviews flat-lined when I was placed into a functionary role.  What are all the metrics about if you don't process and utilize this information?

review_title: Probably a good place to work for
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Despite recently slashes in health insurance benefits, it's still pretty good.  No premiums are always good even if the deductible is very high.
- 401k match superb and plenty of low-fee funds (read: vanguard) available.
- ESPP is amazing, %15 discount with look-back
- Depending on the team you're in (read: not division but actual team) you might have relaxed deadlines.  Note that this heavily depends on the quality of code that the team has.  Teams with crappy code deservedly do a ton of firefighting.
- HR si very good about raises.  They make an effort to adjust your salary to market (in addition to inflation) without you asking.
- Bi-annual bonuses in both cash and stocks (RSUs). 
- Most people honestly enjoy working here.
cons:
- Lots of layoffs recently, job security is iffy.
- Company profitability on a downward trend
- Benefits getting slashed recently (new CEO not very employee friendly at the moment)
- Again, depending on the team you're in, you could deal with really crappy code that'll make your job soul sucking.  There is a ton of legacy code being maintained with no intent to erase technical debt.  This is *not* a software company.  The policy generally is: if it works, ship it.  On a flip side, there are teams with superb code.  Quality of code varies drastically by team.
- Pay is average.  The benefits probably make up for it.
- MIddle-management make waaay too much money (in bonuses) compared to doing work.  Not to mention, management vs low-level peons seems to be 50/50 split, which is just astonishing, given that they are relatively hands-off the products. 
- Performance review isn't merit based.  If could prove P=NP in your first review, and you'll only get a 3.5/5.  On the flip side, you could take a dump on your manager's table on your 6th review and you'll still get a 5/5.  Scores are manipulatied to show "improvement" across reviews and do not reflect the amount of work you've done.

job_title: Senior Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
You get to sample a little bit of everything as a design/analysis engineer. The technologies that Qualcomm is involved in are cool and you get an opportunity to see where the electronics industry is headed in the future. I would say there's a lot of flexibility and job training, depending on what team you're on. There are really smart people at this company...for now. If you're in it for U.S. citizenship it seems that their immigration support is great, but you will work for it. 

The pay is okay compared to most companies.
cons:
The CEO is absolute GARBAGE and so are most of the SVP's. They don't know what they're doing with this company. The culture is dead, benefits are going downhill, engineers are no longer motivated to work, and top talent is leaving. Not to mention the CEO did nothing when immigration was threatened and he paid himself $60.7M during the year of layoffs. The previous CEO cared about his workers, this current one does not. 

The cultural downturn is a drag on your work ethic because everyone is moping around. Teams are now hoarding information in fear of being let go. They're acquiring companies left and right and the jobs are moving overseas. I honestly would say unless you're in it for the H1B and U.S. citizenship, run far FAR away if you have another offer in hand. 

Projects get cancelled before they're completed, even if QC is trying to enter a viable market. I think the company is however large enough that it will survive. They're not opening reqs, so if 10 people from your team leave and there were 20 people to begin with, you're stuck with the work of those 10 people.  Apparently when Paul and Erwin Jacobs were running the company it was more family oriented and the employees were valued.

If Intel catches up to QC's modem technology or they lose the Apple lawsuit, the company is dead. That's sort of a scary thing considering how they're investing billions into it as well. The constant threat of layoffs and lack of perks that other tech companies provide will add way too much stress to your life that it's best just not to care much about your work, which means your career won't grow as best as it should.

review_title: Mostly good, but lots of changes recently
job_title: Staff Hardware Engineer in Raleigh, NC
pros:
The work environment in Raleigh is quite positive and collaborative.  This team started out small, so while we're under the corporate umbrella, the culture here is different than San Diego.  Sure, there are some politics, but those seem to occur mostly when dealing with corporate in San Diego.  

Qualcomm has always tried to compete with the big players when it comes to hiring, so benefits have been more in line with the Googles and Apples of the world than they have been the industry average.  Lots of small perks (free drinks, yearly picnic, etc) and the biggie--free insurance, even for the family.  These are quickly eroding, however. 

We get to do cutting edge engineering work without having to live in a city with a huge cost of living, and we make products we are really proud of.
cons:
Local perception is that Jana partners came in and wants to squeeze us for all we're worth then get out.  Layoffs didn't hit Raleigh too hard (yet) but some of our work was transferred to other sites, so rather than having a tight knit local team, we're spread across time zones.  That was the environment in my previous company and I don't prefer it.  The small perks are going away little by little--many of us watched this happen at previous companies and we know that once cost cutting starts it usually never stops.  Hopefully that won't happen here, but most of us assume it will.  Insurance is still free but starting next year pays out virtually nothing until you hit a (middle range) deductible.  

Overtime is generally expected.  I sometimes get "vacation notices" for people who will be out of town for the weekend.  A lot of people here are in the habit of working at least a little every day, and many of them work an excessive number of hours.  Hard to say if it's expected by management or just a self-imposed drive to keep up with everyone else, but it's way more normal here than at my last company.

Adding a little bit to address my "culture" rating below.  I gave it low marks because the culture of the company as a whole is "California".  Everything is CA-centric, and there is little effort put into making the "satellite" sites integrate into the corporate whole.  My previous company did a much better job of being a group of sites with similar culture throughout.  Qualcomm is CA all the way, and CA values are often at the extreme of the values of the rest of the country (example, we hear about saving water constantly, when it's really only an issue in CA right now).  The culture in Raleigh is mostly task oriented.  We get along, we work together.  We help each other out.  It could be better but for the most part it's very good.

Now with all checks  in India office its almost impossible . Upper management in India has made such process that no one cannot even think to apply across sites ,

Bottom line is its a good company but a not a best company as believed to be . There are lot of Indian companies now a days who pay similar and also has better work culture and policies .
